title: How to Keep Your House Cool Without an Air Conditioner

steps.headline: Keep doors to bedrooms and bathrooms open as much as possible, this will allow better airflow in your house.
Keep the windows open while it is still cool outside.
steps.description: To keep the coolness in the house, close them until the house starts to heat up.

steps.headline: Close shades and blinds on the sunny side of the house.
Open the windows at night.
steps.description: If possible, open a door to the attic or loft; this creates a "stack effect" and the hot air will rise out of the living space.

steps.headline: Buy a fan for your room and some other hot rooms in the house.
steps.description: Circulating hot air feels better than stagnant hot air. Wet a big towel, hang from the ceiling in the pathway of the fan's breeze and close the door. The towel will absorb all the heat in your bedroom. Small wet towels or face-washers can be hung directly over a fan too; just be sure to not have any ends of the towel dangling near the fan blades.

steps.headline: Don't cook anything on the stove.
steps.description: In particular, do not use a gas stove or the oven. Instead, shift your cooking to the outside grill and get some fresh (albeit hot) air.

steps.headline: Cook only in the cool of the evenings or first thing in the morning.
steps.description: Bake early, grill outdoors late. That way, you can keep the heat to a minimum. Enjoy fresh salads, sandwiches and cool foods throughout the day.

steps.headline: Keep lights off as much as possible.
steps.description: Also try to minimize usage of high energy appliances like TV and treadmills.

steps.headline: Turn off all appliances you don't need to use.
Wear short sleeve shirts and shorts.
Change all your bed linen to something lighter and cooler.
steps.description: Put blankets away for the cooler season.

steps.headline: If your sofa or couch fabric is hot, throw sheets over it.
steps.description: This can help stop itching or sticking to the couch while sitting on it. Tuck the sheets in firmly to prevent them from falling off all the time, which will annoy everyone.

text: Basic cooling in the house Keep doors to bedrooms and bathrooms open as much as possible, this will allow better airflow in your house.  Keep the windows open while it is still cool outside. To keep the coolness in the house, close them until the house starts to heat up. Close shades and blinds on the sunny side of the house.  Open the windows at night. If possible, open a door to the attic or loft; this creates a "stack effect" and the hot air will rise out of the living space. Buy a fan for your room and some other hot rooms in the house. Circulating hot air feels better than stagnant hot air. Wet a big towel, hang from the ceiling in the pathway of the fan's breeze and close the door. The towel will absorb all the heat in your bedroom. Small wet towels or face-washers can be hung directly over a fan too; just be sure to not have any ends of the towel dangling near the fan blades. Cooking Don't cook anything on the stove. In particular, do not use a gas stove or the oven. Instead, shift your cooking to the outside grill and get some fresh (albeit hot) air. Cook only in the cool of the evenings or first thing in the morning. Bake early, grill outdoors late. That way, you can keep the heat to a minimum. Enjoy fresh salads, sandwiches and cool foods throughout the day. Energy usage Keep lights off as much as possible. Also try to minimize usage of high energy appliances like TV and treadmills. Turn off all appliances you don't need to use.  Fabrics Wear short sleeve shirts and shorts.  Change all your bed linen to something lighter and cooler. Put blankets away for the cooler season. If your sofa or couch fabric is hot, throw sheets over it. This can help stop itching or sticking to the couch while sitting on it. Tuck the sheets in firmly to prevent them from falling off all the time, which will annoy everyone.
